awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Simultaneously Controlling Multi-Scale Material Structures Based on Fluid Layering With Self-Assembly and Eutectic Growth
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to develop high performance bulk thermoelectric materials by manipulating their structures at the meso-, micro-, and nano-scale. Achieving a broad range of length scales in the structure of thermoelectric materials is expected to maximize phonon scattering, which will in turn maximize the performance of thermoelectric materials due to the depletion of phononic (or lattice) thermal conduction. Here, the novel idea is to utilize continuum-level fluid mechanics (layering technique) for designing meso/micro-scale structures while creating micro/nano-scale structures with self-assembly and eutectic growth. Through meso-/micro-scale layering and structuring with liquid phase precursors, the size and distribution of nanoparticle inoculants will be manipulated to control the heterogeneous nucleation and solid phase formation at micro-/nano-scales. This new out-of-the-box but high-risk approach integrating fluid mechanics into materials science/engineering will provide new insight and research direction.
 
Thermoelectric energy conversion systems offer an excellent strategy for improving sustainability of our electric power base by scavenging waste heat from various power consuming systems including automobiles and power plants or for providing effective compact cooling for computers and electronic devices with robustness and silence. The research will provide rational and novel methodologies of improving their efficiency by modifying material structures. In addition, research outcomes include crucial knowledge for fully utilizing nanoparticles by solving one of the major hurdles, nanoparticle aggregation. This new approach combining continuum level fluid mechanics and controlling structures down to nanoscale related to material science/engineering may bring subsequent research related to rational design of multi-scale structured materials. The research also include training of Ph.D students with experience in interdisciplinary collaborative research; broadening participation of undergraduate students belonging to underrepresented groups through the NSF-funded Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation at Texas A&M University and the Center for Enhancement of Engineering Diversity at Virgina Tech; and integrating nanoscale thermal transport phenomena into undergraduate/graduate courses.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Thermoelectric (TE) energy conversion systems offer an excellent strategy for improving sustainability of our electric power base by scavenging waste heat or for providing effective compact cooling with robustness and silence.  Unfortunately, TE generators have been too inefficient to be cost-effective in many applications.  Maximization of TE figure of merit requires a low thermal conductivity, which can be obtained by phonon scattering.   

The main outcome from this awarded project is the discovery of effective way of improving thermoelectric figure of merit of a material.  One of the key outcomes has shown the influence of nanoparticle insertion into a host matrix on thermal conductivity, electrical conductivity, and thermopower, which are the three key properties that determine the efficiency of thermoelectric systems. Through the nanoparticle insertion and facile current assisted sintering method, we developed materials with multi-scale structures, which promote phonon scattering and thereby decrease thermal conductivity.

Specifically, magnesium silicide-stannide solid solution systems have been used as our model for the host matrix, and metal oxide nanoparticles were used for controlling material structures so as to reduce lattice thermal conductivity. This material is one of the most promising thermoelectric materials for practical applications because they contain only inexpensive and environmentally benign materials in contrast to typical thermoelectric materials made of toxic and rare earth elements. We found that this solid solution is subject to severe phase segregation through systematic studies, for the first time when it is under prolonged operation. This phase segregation turned out to be detrimental to thermoelectric performance because it lessens phonon alloy scattering and thereby increases lattice thermal conductivity. Here the introduction of nanoparticles creates additional phonon scattering, which have suppressed lattice thermal conductivity and maintained low thermal conductivity. Our studies revealed the problems of this type of solid solution materials, and suggested potential solutions to alleviate the problem.

Research outcomes were disseminated through research papers and conference presentation. In addition, graduate students were educated through comprehensive experimental and computational studies. Undergraduate students were also exposed to thermoelectric energy conversion, and had experience in designing thermoelectric systems.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/20/2016
Modified by: Choongho Yu
